claims.claim: TRAPPIST-1 b favors a non-zero heat redistribution, implying the presence of an atmosphere.

evidence.quote: | Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) | 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) | 0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit | Non-zero redistribution is favored |
A non-zero redistribution parameter implies transport beyond an immediate bare-rock reradiation limit.

claims.caveat: Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.

claims.claim: Spectral structures near 15 um indicate atmospheric absorption, favoring CO2-rich scenarios.

evidence.quote: | 15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate | 96 ppm | Flat-spectrum null | Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption |
Spectral structure near 15 um provides composition-sensitive evidence, especially for CO2-rich scenarios.

claims.caveat: Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.

claims.claim: Joint modeling of phase curve and spectral data prefers atmosphere-bearing models over a bare rock model.

evidence.quote: | Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere) | 7.4 | 1.0 baseline ratio | Atmosphere-bearing models better explain combined data products |
Joint constraints from phase curve and spectrum are stronger than either observable alone.

claims.caveat: O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current data.

claims.claim: Night-side and composition uncertainties require further observational evidence to be resolved.

evidence.quote: Remaining degeneracies motivate broader wavelength coverage and repeated observations.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.

claims.caveat: Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
